data.text: The struggle for independence
During the British rule in the subcontinent, the officers of the army were all British and the soldiers Hindus, Muslims, or Sikhs.
The soldiers revolted in 1857 due to the introduction of controversial bullets greased with animal fat.
The battle fought between the soldiers against the British is called the War of Independence.
The soldiers were defeated and the Mughal King Bahadur Shah Zafar was sent into exile in Rangoon.
Some educated people started the Indian National Congress in 1885.
The National Congress became powerful under the leadership of Mohandas Gandhi.
Some Muslim leaders formed the All India Muslim League in 1906.
The Muslims believed that if the British left India the Hindus would take control of the country.
The Muslims were inspired by leaders like Sir Syed Ahmed Khan.
Sir Syed advocated that the Muslims educate themselves and improve their situation.
Leaders of Muslim league.
Sir Mohammad Iqbal put forward the idea of a separate state for the Muslims at Allahabad in 1930.
The most famous Muslim leader at that time was a lawyer named Mohammed Ali Jinnah.
After a long struggle and many discussions with the British, two countries were formed—India and Pakistan.
The areas where the majority of the population was Muslim became Pakistan.
The remaining parts became India or Bharat.
Pakistan became an independent country on 14 August 1947.
